episodeTitle: Eternal Friends! The Vowed Bell Echoes Across the Mighty Seas!
description: The tragic tale of Noland and Kalgara concludes as their friendship is restored when the truth about the sacred trees is revealed. Despite promises to reunite, both men die without seeing each other again - Noland executed as a liar, Kalgara defending Shandia in the sky. In the present, Enel begins destroying Skypiea as Luffy and Nami race toward the Golden Bell.

events.title: Mousse Discovers the Truth About Tree Fever
events.description: Mousse realizes that the trees Noland cut down were infected with Tree Fever, a deadly plague that spreads through trees. Noland's crew destroyed the sacred Forest of Embodiment not out of disrespect, but to save the entire island and village from the disease.
events.significance: This revelation resolves the central conflict between Noland and the Shandians, transforming their relationship from enemies to friends and demonstrating the clash between superstition and scientific understanding.

quotes.text: The trees were sick! That's why he cut them down! He was trying to save us!
quotes.speaker: Mousse
quotes.context: Mousse explaining to her father Kalgara why Noland destroyed the sacred trees

events.title: Kalgara and Noland's Reconciliation
events.description: Upon learning the truth about Tree Fever, Kalgara rushes to the shore to apologize to Noland as his ship is departing. The two warriors reconcile, with Kalgara acknowledging that Noland saved his people despite the cultural misunderstanding.
events.significance: This moment cements one of the most powerful friendships in One Piece, built on mutual respect and understanding across cultural divides. It sets up the tragic promise that will never be fulfilled.

quotes.text: I'm sorry, Noland! Please forgive my ignorance!
quotes.speaker: Kalgara
quotes.context: Kalgara apologizing for misunderstanding Noland's intentions

events.title: The Promise of the Golden Bell
events.description: As Noland's ship departs, Kalgara vows to ring the Golden Bell every day so that Noland can find his way back to Jaya, even through the worst storms. The Shandians ring the bell as a beacon and a promise of eternal friendship, with Noland tearfully vowing to return.
events.significance: The Golden Bell becomes a symbol of their unbreakable bond and unfulfilled promise. This moment is central to the entire Skypiea Arc's emotional core and connects to Luffy's eventual ringing of the bell 400 years later.

quotes.text: We will ring this bell! Ring it loud so you'll always find your way back to us, Noland! No matter how fierce the storm!
quotes.speaker: Kalgara
quotes.context: Kalgara's promise to Noland as he departs

quotes.text: I will return! I promise you, Kalgara! We will meet again!
quotes.speaker: Noland
quotes.context: Noland's vow to return to Jaya

events.title: Noland Returns to Jaya with King Aruyutayan V
events.description: Five years later, Noland returns to Jaya with King Aruyutayan V of Lvneel to show him the City of Gold. However, the Knock Up Stream has sent half of Jaya - including Shandora and the Golden Bell - into the sky, leaving only jungle where the city once stood.
events.significance: This is the catastrophic event that seals both men's fates and creates the central mystery of the Skypiea Arc. It explains why Shandora is in the sky and why Noland was branded a liar.

quotes.text: This is impossible... The city... Where is the city?! Kalgara! The bell!
quotes.speaker: Noland
quotes.context: Noland's shock upon discovering Shandora has vanished

events.title: Mont Blanc Noland's Execution
events.description: Noland is publicly executed in Lvneel Kingdom for allegedly deceiving the king about the City of Gold. Despite his crew's protests and his own certainty about what he saw, Noland maintains his integrity to the end. A false crew member testifies against him, and the king silences Noland's real crew to cover his embarrassment.
events.significance: Noland's death transforms him into 'Liar Noland,' a cautionary tale told to children across the North Blue for 400 years. His execution sets up Cricket's quest to restore his ancestor's honor and establishes one of the series' most tragic misunderstandings.

quotes.text: The city of gold exists! I saw it with my own eyes! I am no liar!
quotes.speaker: Noland

events.title: The Knock Up Stream Sends Jaya to the Sky
events.description: A massive Knock Up Stream erupts beneath Jaya, propelling half of the island - including Shandora, the Golden Bell, and the Forest of Embodiment - 10,000 meters into the sky. Kalgara and the Shandians witness their land being torn apart and sent skyward during a war with the Skypieans.
events.significance: This cataclysmic event creates Skypiea's landmass, establishes the 400-year war between Shandians and Skypieans, and explains why the City of Gold vanished. It's one of the most important world-building events in the entire series.

events.title: Kalgara's Death in Battle
events.description: Kalgara dies fighting against the Skypieans after his land is sent to the sky. In his final moments, he desperately wishes he could ring the Golden Bell one more time to let Noland know they are still alive. He dies never knowing that Noland has already been executed.
events.significance: Kalgara's death while trying to reach the bell mirrors Noland's death believing in the city's existence. Both men die without fulfilling their promise to reunite, creating one of the series' most heartbreaking tragedies. This motivates Wyper's quest 400 years later.

quotes.text: If only I could ring that bell one more time... Noland would know... we're still here... still alive...
quotes.speaker: Kalgara

events.title: Young Wyper Learns of Kalgara's Promise
events.description: In a flashback, young Wyper learns from the Shandia chief about Kalgara's unfulfilled promise to ring the Golden Bell for Noland. The chief tells Wyper that they must ring the bell so Noland can hear it from heaven, as they are now closer to the sky.
events.significance: This reveals Wyper's motivation for fighting to reclaim Shandora and ring the bell. It connects the past tragedy to the present conflict and shows how Kalgara's promise has been passed down through generations.

quotes.text: We must ring that bell, Wyper. For our ancestor Kalgara, and for his friend Noland who waits in heaven.
quotes.speaker: Shandia Chief
quotes.context: Explaining Kalgara's promise to young Wyper

events.title: Enel Begins Destroying Skypiea
events.description: In the present day, Enel unleashes massive lightning strikes on Skypiea, targeting the Shandia Village, God's Shrine, and preparing to obliterate Angel Island. Citizens evacuate as Enel's destructive power is unleashed across the sky islands.
events.significance: This marks the escalation of the Skypiea Arc's climax, with Enel attempting to destroy everything. It creates urgency for Luffy to defeat him and ring the bell before Skypiea is completely destroyed.

events.title: Luffy and Nami Race to the Golden Bell
events.description: Luffy and Nami climb Giant Jack toward the Golden Bell, determined to stop Enel and ring the bell. Luffy is driven by his desire to defeat Enel, while both are racing against time as Enel's destruction continues.
events.significance: This sets up the arc's climactic confrontation and the eventual ringing of the bell that will fulfill the 400-year-old promise between Noland and Kalgara.

quotes.text: I'm gonna send that Enel flying!
quotes.speaker: Luffy

quotes.text: We will ring this bell! Ring it loud so you'll always find your way back to us, Noland! No matter how fierce the storm!
quotes.speaker: Kalgara

quotes.text: I will return! I promise you, Kalgara! We will meet again!
quotes.speaker: Noland
quotes.context: Noland's vow to return to Jaya

quotes.text: The city of gold exists! I saw it with my own eyes! I am no liar!
quotes.speaker: Noland

quotes.text: If only I could ring that bell one more time... Noland would know... we're still here... still alive...
quotes.speaker: Kalgara

themes.description: The episode centers on the tragic unfulfilled promise between Noland and Kalgara. Both men die believing they failed each other, never knowing the other's true fate. Their promise to reunite becomes a 400-year quest for their descendants.
themes.symbolism: The Golden Bell represents the promise itself - a beacon of hope that goes unheard. The silence of the bell for 400 years symbolizes broken communication and lost friendship.
culturalReferences: The concept of honor and promises (yakusoku) in Japanese culture
The tragedy of miscommunication across cultures

themes.description: Noland tells the truth about the City of Gold but is branded 'Liar Noland' because circumstances made the truth appear false. The episode explores how truth can be destroyed by timing and misfortune.
themes.symbolism: The vanished city represents how truth can disappear, leaving only perception. Noland's execution shows how society creates narratives that erase inconvenient truths.
culturalReferences: Historical martyrs who died for truths that were later proven

themes.description: Wyper inherits Kalgara's promise to ring the bell for Noland, showing how the will of ancestors lives on through descendants. This is a core One Piece theme - dreams and promises transcending death.
themes.symbolism: Wyper's tattoos and fighting style mirror Kalgara's, symbolizing the physical manifestation of inherited will.
culturalReferences: Japanese concept of family honor and ancestral duty
The passing of responsibilities across generations

themes.description: The conflict between Noland and the Shandians initially stems from Noland's scientific approach clashing with Shandia's spiritual beliefs. The resolution comes when both sides acknowledge the value of the other's worldview.
themes.symbolism: The diseased trees represent how tradition and superstition can be harmful when they prevent practical solutions to real problems.
culturalReferences: Historical conflicts between scientific progress and traditional beliefs
The Meiji Restoration's clash between Western science and Japanese tradition

themes.description: Noland and Kalgara's friendship transcends cultural, philosophical, and temporal boundaries. Their bond is so strong it echoes across 400 years and inspires Luffy's generation to fulfill what they could not.
themes.symbolism: The ringing of the bell represents communication and connection across impossible distances - from sea to sky, from past to present, from the living to the dead.
culturalReferences: The concept of nakama (fellowship/companionship) central to One Piece

characterSpotlights.development: Noland's complete arc is shown - from brave explorer to misunderstood hero to executed 'liar.' His unwavering integrity in the face of death cements him as a noble character whose truth was destroyed by fate.
keyActions: Saving the Shandians from Tree Fever
Maintaining his truthfulness even at his execution
quotes: The city of gold exists! I saw it with my own eyes! I am no liar!
I will return! I promise you, Kalgara! We will meet again!

characterSpotlights.development: Kalgara evolves from suspicious warrior to devoted friend. His promise to ring the bell daily and his death trying to reach it show the depth of his loyalty and the tragedy of circumstances beyond his control.
keyActions: Forgiving Noland and rushing to the shore
Promising to ring the Golden Bell as a beacon
Fighting to protect Shandia in the sky
Dying while wishing to ring the bell for Noland
quotes: We will ring this bell! Ring it loud so you'll always find your way back to us, Noland!
If only I could ring that bell one more time... Noland would know... we're still here...

characterSpotlights.development: Wyper's flashback reveals the source of his intense drive to reclaim Shandora and ring the bell. His motivation transforms from simple revenge to fulfilling a 400-year-old promise of friendship.
keyActions: Learning about Kalgara's promise as a child
Vowing to ring the bell for his ancestor

characterSpotlights.development: Though less prominent in this episode, Luffy's race to the Golden Bell is given new meaning by the backstory. He unknowingly moves toward fulfilling Noland and Kalgara's promise.
quotes: I'm gonna send that Enel flying!

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extends several emotional scenes, particularly the bell-ringing sequence and the execution scene, with additional reaction shots and extended music.
The anime adds more visual detail to the Knock Up Stream event, showing the massive scale of destruction and the island being torn apart.
Additional scenes of Enel's destruction in the present day are expanded compared to the manga panels.

trivia.fact: This episode adapts chapters 291-293 of the manga, covering crucial backstory and present-day events simultaneously.
The Japanese title uses the word 'eien' (永遠) meaning 'eternal' or 'forever,' emphasizing the timeless nature of Noland and Kalgara's friendship.
Masaki Aizawa voices both Kalgara and his descendant Wyper, emphasizing the inherited will theme.
The ending song 'Tsuki to Taiyo' (Moon and Sun) is thematically appropriate for this episode, as it reflects the separated but connected nature of Noland and Kalgara - one on earth, one in the sky.
Mont Blanc Noland's execution date is stated as May 21, 1127 in the story's calendar, exactly 400 years before the Straw Hats' adventure.

sources.title: Mont Blanc Noland - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: The Lvneel Kingdom published a children's book called 'Liar Noland' to cover up the king's embarrassment, which becomes famous across the North Blue for 400 years.
